question: How does Mr. Darbey's status as an officer of the Hussars relate to his being seen by The Dean and spoken to by Sheba?
gold_answer: The Dean sees Darbey, Mr. Darbey is an officer of the Hussars, Sheba speaks to Mr. Darbey.
llm_answer: Mr. Darbey is seen by The Dean and spoken to by Sheba as a visitor to the Deanery, specifically as a suitor for Salome's hand in marriage.

context.text: girl--period uncertain--Ten guineas." SHEBA. Less than yours! What a shame! SALOME. "Trimmings, linings, buttons, frillings--Five guineas! Extras, Two guineas. Total, Forty pounds, nineteen. Ladies' own brown paper patterns mislaid. Terms, Cash!" [_They throw themselves into each other's arms._ SALOME. Oh, Sheba! SHEBA. Salome! Are there forty pounds in the wide world? SALOME. My heart weighs twenty. What shall we do? SHEBA. If we were only a few years older I should suggest that we wrote nice notes to Papa and committed suicide. SALOME. Brought up as we have been, that's out of the question! SHEBA. Then let us be brave women and wear the dresses! SALOME. Of course we'll do that, but--the bill! SHEBA. We must get dear Papa in a good humor and coax him to make us a present of money. He knows we haven't been charitable in the town for ever so long. SALOME. Poor dear Papa! He hasn't paid our proper dressmaker's bill yet, and I'm sure he's pressed for money. SHEBA. But we can't help that when _we're_ pressed for money--poor dear Papa! SALOME. Suppose poor Papa refuses to give us a present? SHEBA. Then we must play the

pressed for money--poor dear Papa! SALOME. Suppose poor Papa refuses to give us a present? SHEBA. Then we must play the piano when he's at work on his Concordance--poor dear Papa! SALOME. However, don't let us wrong poor Papa in advance. Let us try to think how nice we shall look. SHEBA. Oh yes--sha'n't I! SALOME. Oh, I shall! And as for stealing out of the house with Major Tarver when poor dear Papa has gone to bed, why, Gerald Tarver would die for me! SHEBA. So would Nugent Darbey for me; besides I'm not old enough to know better. SALOME. You're not so very much younger than I, Sheba! SHEBA. Indeed, Salome! Then why do you keep me in short skirts? SALOME. Why! you cruel girl! You know I can't lengthen you till I'm married! [_BLORE, the butler, a venerable-looking person, with rather a clerical suggestion about his dress, enters by the window._ BLORE. [_Benignly._] The two soldier gentlemen have just rode hup, Miss Salome. [_The girls clutch each other's hands._ SALOME. You mean Major Tarver? SHEBA. And Mr. Darbey. They have called to inquire after poor Papa. SALOME. Poor Papa!

TRISTRAM. Get back then--get back! [_SIR TRISTRAM and GEORGIANA pace up and down excitedly._ HATCHAM. Right, Sir. There's only one mortal fear I've got about our Dandy. GEORGIANA _and_ SIR TRISTRAM. What's that? HATCHAM. He 'asn't found out about 'is tail yet, sir, and when he does it'll fret him, as sure as my name's Bob Hatcham. SIR TRISTRAM. Keep the stable pitch dark--he mayn't notice it. HATCHAM. Not to-night, sir, but he's a proud 'orse and what'll he think of 'isself on the 'ill to-morrow? You and me and the lady, sir--it 'ud be different with us, but how's our Dandy to hide his bereavement? [_HATCHAM goes out of the window with SIR TRISTRAM as THE DEAN enters, followed by BLORE, who carries a lighted lantern._ THE DEAN. [_Looking reproachfully at GEORGIANA._] You have returned, Georgiana? GEORGIANA. Yes, thank ye. THE DEAN. And that animal? GEORGIANA. In our stables, safe and snug. THE DEAN. [_With a groan._] Oh! GEORGIANA. You can sleep to-night

custody while my face was unofficially held downwards in the mud. The villain has been traced back to the Deanery. SIR TRISTRAM. Go away! HANNAH. Come away! NOAH. The man was a unknown lover of my nooly made wife! GEORGIANA. You mustn't bring your domestic affairs here; this is a subject for your own fireside of an evening. [_THE DEAN appears outside the window with SALOME, SHEBA, TARVER and DARBEY._ THE DEAN. [_Outside._] Come in, Major Tarver--come in, Mr. Darbey! NOAH. That's his voice! _THE DEAN enters, followed by SALOME, TARVER, SHEBA and DARBEY._ NOAH. [_Confronting THE DEAN._] My man. HANNAH. No, no, Noahry! GEORGIANA. You're speaking to Dr. Jedd, the Dean of St. Marvells. NOAH. I'm speaking to the man I took last night--the culprit as 'as allynated the affections of my wife. SIR TRISTRAM. Wait--one moment! [_Going out at the window._ [_SALOME and TARVER go into the Library and sit at the writing-table. DARBEY sits in an arm-chair with SHEBA on the arm._ THE DEAN. [_Mildly._]

Tarver. SHEBA. Mr. Darbey. TARVER. [_Taking SALOME'S hand eagerly._] My dear Miss Jedd! DARBEY. [_Rising and putting a glass to his eye._] Hah yah! Hah yah! SALOME. [_With her hand on her heart._] You quite startled us. TARVER. [_In an agony of contrition._] Oh, did we? DARBEY. Awfully cut up to hear it. SHEBA. We never dreamt of finding two visitors for Papa. BLORE. Why, you told me to show the gentlemen hin, Miss Sheba! [_The two girls start guiltily and glare at BLORE._ SALOME. [_With suppressed rage_.] You needn't wait, Blore! BLORE. [_To himself._] Let 'em 'ang that on the 'atstand! [_BLORE goes out. DARBEY and SHEBA stroll together into the Library._ TARVER. [_To SALOME._] We thought we'd ride over directly after parade to make the final arrangements for tonight. Have the costumes arrived? SALOME. Yes, they came yesterday in a hamper labeled "Miss Jedd, Secretary, Cast-off Clothing Distribution League." TARVER. That was my idea--came to me in the middle of the night. SALOME. Dear Major Tarver, surely this terrible strain on your nerves is very,

and Rejoice. [_The two girls cling to each other as BLORE comes from the Library with two letters on a salver._ BLORE. The second post, sir--just hin. THE DEAN. [_Blandly._] Thank you. BLORE. [_Hearing SALOME and SHEBA crying._] They've 'ad a scolding, 'ussies. Let 'em 'ang that on the 'atstand! [_He is going out._ THE DEAN. [_Opening letters._] Oh, Blore! This note from Mr. Hodder, the Secretary of "The Sport and Relaxation Repression Guild," reminds me that to-morrow is the first day of the Races--the St. Marvells Spring Meeting, as it is called. BLORE. Hindeed, sir--fancy that! And I not know it! THE DEAN. All our servants may not resemble you, Blore. Pray remind them in the kitchen and the stable of the rule of the house---- BLORE. No servant allowed to leave the Deanery, on hany pretence, while the Races is on. THE DEAN. [_Kindly._] While the races _are_ on--thank you, Blore. [_Opens his second letter._ BLORE. Thank _you,_ sir. [_To himself._] Oh, if the Dean only knew the good thing I could put him on to

Papa! THE DEAN. To your rooms! I am distracted! SALOME. Major Tarver and Mr. Darbey!---- THE DEAN. If you have sufficiently merged all sense of moral rectitude as to declare that I am not at home, do so. SHEBA. No, no. Papa; we have accidentally discovered that you, our parent, have stooped to deception, if not to crime. THE DEAN. [_Staggering back._] Oh! SHEBA. We are still young--the sooner, therefore, we are removed from any unfortunate influence the better. SALOME. We have an opportunity of beginning life afresh. SHEBA. These two gallant gentlemen have proposed for us. THE DEAN. Then I _am_ at home. Where are they? [_He goes out rapidly, followed by SALOME and SHEBA. Directly they have disappeared, NOAH TOPPING, looking dishevelled, rushes in at the window, with HANNAH clinging to him._ NOAH. [_Glaring round the room._] Is this 'ere the Deanery? [_GEORGIANA and SIR TRISTRAM come to him._ HANNAH. Noahry, Noah, come back! NOAH. Theer's been a man rescued from my lawful custody while my face was unofficially held downwards in the mud. The villain has been traced back to the Deanery. SIR TRISTRAM.

I don't know, toy-child. But at length retribution came. Ill luck fell upon her--her horses, stock, everything, came to the hammer. That was my hour. "Come to me," I wrote, "my children yearn for you." SHEBA _and_ SALOME. [_With wry faces._] Oh! THE DEAN. "At the Deanery of St. Marvells, with the cares of a household, and a stable which contains only a thirteen-year-old pony, you may obtain rest and forgetfulness." And she is coming! SHEBA _and_ SALOME. When? Oh! when? THE DEAN. She merely says, "Soon." SHEBA _and_ SALOME. [_Stamping with vexation._] Ugh! THE DEAN. Salome, Sheba, you will, I fear, find her a sad broken creature, a weary fragment, a wave-tossed derelict. Let it be your patient endeavor to win back a flickering smile to the wan features of this chastened widow. _BLORE enters with a telegram._ BLORE. A telegram, sir! [_THE DEAN opens telegram._ SHEBA. No Aunt Tidman flickers a smile at me! SALOME. I wouldn't be in her shoes for something! SHEBA. Salt in her bed, Salome! SALOME. Yes, and the peg out of the rattling window!

_me,_ sir? THE DEAN Lock up; I'll speak to you in the morning. Lock up. [_BLORE goes into the Library, turns out the lamp there, and disappears._ What dreadful wave threatens to engulf the Deanery? What has come to us in a few fatal hours? A horse of sporting tendencies contaminating my stables, his equally vicious owner nestling in the nursery, and my own widowed sister, in all probability, smoking a cigarette at her bedroom window with her feet on the window-ledge! [_Listening._] What's that? [_He peers through the window curtains._] I thought I heard footsteps in the garden. I can see nothing--only the old spire standing out against the threatening sky. [_Leaving the window shudderingly._] The Spire! My principal creditor! My principal creditor, the most conspicuous object in the city! _BLORE re-enters with his lantern, carrying some bank-notes in his hand._ BLORE. [_Laying the notes on the table._] I found these, sir, on your dressing-table--they're bank-notes, sir. THE DEAN. [_Taking the notes._] Thank you. I placed them there to be sent to the Bank to-morrow. [_Counting the notes._] Ten--ten--twenty--five--five, fifty. Fifty pounds! The very sum Georgiana urged me to--oh! [_To

Ten--ten--twenty--five--five, fifty. Fifty pounds! The very sum Georgiana urged me to--oh! [_To BLORE, waving him away._] Leave me--go to bed--go to bed--go to bed! [_BLORE is going._] Blore! BLORE. Sir? THE DEAN. What made you tempt me with these at such a moment? BLORE. Temp' you, sir! The window was hopen, and I feared they might blow away. THE DEAN. [_Catching him by the coat collar._] Man, what were you doing at St. Marvells Races last summer? BLORE. [_With a cry, falling on his knees._] Oh, sir! Oh, sir! I knew that 'igh-sperited lady would bring grief and sorrow to the peaceful, 'appy Deanery! Oh, sir, I _'ave_ done a little on my hown account from time to time on the 'ill, halso hon commission for the kitchen! THE DEAN. I knew it--I knew it! BLORE. Oh, sir, you are a old gentleman--turn a charitable 'art to the Races! It's a wicious institution what spends more ready money in St. Marvells than us good people do in a year. THE DEAN. Get up, Blore--get up. Oh, Edward Blore, Edward

communities.summary:
1. **Title**: The Deanery's Turmoil
2. **Summary**: The Dean of St. Marvells is facing financial struggles, particularly with the restoration of the church spire, and is being influenced by his sister Georgiana to engage in horse racing as a means to raise funds. Meanwhile, the Dean's daughters, Salome and Sheba, are navigating their own relationships and futures. The story is filled with themes of morality, deception, and the complexities of family dynamics. The Dean's attempts to maintain his dignity and reputation are constantly challenged by the events unfolding around him. As the story progresses, the characters' true nature and intentions are revealed, leading to a deeper understanding of the Deanery's turmoil.
3. **Keywords**: Deanery, Horse Racing, Family Dynamics, Morality, Deception

1. **Title**: The Dean's Household
2. **Summary**: The given text chunks appear to be excerpts from a novel, focusing on the daily life and interactions of the Dean's household, including the Dean, his daughters Georgiana, Salome, and Sheba, and various guests and acquaintances. The conversations and events revolve around social gatherings, discussions about a potential restoration of the Minster Spire, and the Dean's interactions with his family and community members. The tone is often humorous and lighthearted, with witty remarks and comedic situations. The characters' personalities and relationships are also explored, revealing their quirks, interests, and values.
3. **Keywords**: Dean's Household, Social Gatherings, Minster Spire, Family Dynamics, Humor

1. **Title**: Sterne's Influence on German Literature
2. **Summary**: The provided text chunks discuss the influence of Laurence Sterne, an English author, on German literature, particularly in the 18th century. Sterne's works, such as "A Sentimental Journey", were widely read and admired in Germany, and his writing style and themes were emulated by many German authors, including Goethe. The chunks also touch on the topic of plagiarism, with some authors accusing Goethe of borrowing from Sterne without proper attribution. The discussion highlights the significant impact of Sterne's work on the development of German literature during this period. The influence of Sterne's sentimental and humorous style can be seen in the works of various German authors, and his legacy continued to be felt in German literary circles long after his death. Overall, the text chunks provide a comprehensive overview of Sterne's influence on German literature, including his impact on notable authors and the literary movements of the time.
3. **Keywords**: Sterne, German Literature, 18th Century, Goethe, Plagiarism

1. **Title**: The Dean's Disappearance
2. **Summary**: The Dean of St. Marvells has mysteriously disappeared, and his family and friends are searching for him. The story revolves around the events leading up to his disappearance, including a fire at the local Swan Inn, a horse named Dandy, and a complex web of relationships and motives. The Dean's sister, Georgiana, and her friend, Sir Tristram, are trying to uncover the truth behind the Dean's disappearance, while dealing with the local constable, Noah, who seems to be hiding information. As the story unfolds, it becomes clear that the Dean was involved in some questionable activities, and his disappearance may be linked to a larger scandal.
3. **Keywords**: Disappearance, Dean, Mystery, Scandal, Family Secrets

1. **Title**: Life in Canada City
2. **Summary**: The text chunks describe life in Canada City, a mining town, focusing on the experiences of its young women, particularly Cissy Trixit, the daughter of a prominent banker. The community is portrayed as vibrant, with social interactions and relationships between characters like Cissy, her friend Piney, and various men, including the Reverend Mr. Windibrook and a young engineer. The narrative touches on themes of beauty, social status, and the complexities of human connections in a small, close-knit community. The stories also mention the town's layout, its church, and the contrast between the natural beauty of the surrounding landscape and the harsh realities of mining life.
3. **Keywords**: Canada City, Mining Town, Social Interactions, Cissy Trixit, Community Life

1. **Title**: Poverty and Human Struggle
2. **Summary**: The given text chunks revolve around themes of poverty, struggle, and human connection. The narrative follows characters like Rags, who is taking care of a baby in a tenement, and Young Harringford, known as the "Goodwood Plunger," who is struggling with his own demons. The stories depict the harsh realities of life in poverty, the importance of human relationships, and the struggles of individuals trying to survive and find meaning in their lives. The texts also touch on the contrast between the lives of the poor and the wealthy, highlighting the difficulties faced by those living in poverty. Through the characters' experiences, the narrative conveys a sense of desperation, hope, and resilience.
3. **Keywords**: Poverty, Struggle, Human Connection, Survival, Resilience

1. **Title**: Riots and Secret Societies
2. **Summary**: The text chunks revolve around a storyline of impending riots and the involvement of secret societies, specifically the Triad and the White Lotus. The characters, including Heywood and Wutzler, navigate a complex web of alliances, rivalries, and hidden agendas. The narrative touches on themes of loyalty, deception, and survival amidst the looming threat of violence and persecution. As the story unfolds, the characters must use their wits and resources to stay one step ahead of their adversaries and uncover the truth about the secret societies.
3. **Keywords**: Triad, White Lotus, Riots, Secret Societies, Persecution

1. **Title**: Family Drama and Inheritance
2. **Summary**: The text chunks revolve around the themes of family, inheritance, and social status. Aunt Patsy, a wealthy and stylish woman, navigates her relationships with her poor relatives, including her nephew Jim. Meanwhile, Roxie Daymon and Governor Morock engage in discussions about the Simon estate and the potential for financial gain. The narrative also touches on the history of the characters, including their family backgrounds and past experiences. As the story unfolds, it becomes clear that the characters are entangled in a complex web of family dynamics, power struggles, and financial interests. The late civil war between the States of the American Union is also mentioned, highlighting the broader historical context in which the story takes place.
3. **Keywords**: Inheritance, Family Drama, Social Status, Power Struggle, American Civil War

1. **Title**: Self-Discovery and Human Nature
2. **Summary**: The text chunks explore the themes of self-discovery, human nature, and the complexities of personal relationships. The narrator reflects on their own life, acknowledging feelings of loneliness and disconnection, despite being part of society. They also examine the tendency to seek validation and approval from others, and the dangers of egoism and self-importance. The chunks also touch on the idea that true understanding of oneself and others can only be achieved through honest self-reflection and empathy. The narrator critiques the tendency to present a false image of oneself, and the importance of authenticity in personal relationships.
3. **Keywords**: Self-Discovery, Human Nature, Authenticity, Empathy, Egoism
